This movie is nothing short of a dark, gritty masterpiece. I may be bias, as the Apartheid era is an area I've always felt for South Africans. The problems they have are immense, and only solutions of varying degree are contemplated and implemented. The movie is as dark and depressing as the Apartheid period, interspersed with small comedic moments that made me laugh. Bigelow deftly avoids making it blatant by continually staying true to the experience.

Movie about two Australian girls--Debbie (Nell Schofield) and Sue (Sue Knight)--and what happens when they become girlfriends of two surly bikers--Skyeler (Lloyd Morris) and Gammy (Sandy Harbutt). Interesting look at the seamy underbelly of Hobart, and how the "young men and women leave Hobart for Victoria..." Good music, and Saxon-like bikers. Out-of-print VHS.<|end_of_text|>

Okay. Here's the thing. I've read through the comments of other viewers --- some trashing the film and some saying it's the funniest, most enjoyable work of kubrick they've seen. This movie is good for some laughs and i think many are as surprised as i am over kubrick's level of comedy here.
Compared to Full Metal Jacket and A Clockwork Orange , it seems much less mature. But it's just as relevant and charming

A woman who hates cats (Alice Krige) and her son (Brian Krause) have moved into a small town, and must deal with a mean cat. The cat, whom Alice has brought with her, comes to life as it senses her dark hatred. Well, it turns out that she and her son are not what they seem, and the townspeople have a fight on their hands. Made for TV.
